free_text.Learning outcomes: Introduction to the main physical methods that are used to investigate the structure and dynamics of biological macromolecules. Although these lectures are offered in the Physics department, they are of equal interest to students with a background in Life Sciences, who will have the opportunity to acquire a conceptual knowledge of the physical methods used in structural biology, thus avoiding the widespread attitude to consider these techniques as "black boxes".[br/]
free_text.Content: [b]-	Introduction[/b][br/][li]	Scattering of X-rays, neutrons, electrons by biological materials.[br/][b]-	Diffraction and Fourier transforms[/b][br/][li]	Fourier series and transforms. Convolution products. Applications of the convolution theorem in diffraction methods.[br/][b]-	Macromolecular X-ray crystallography[/b][br/][li]	Diffraction of X-rays from crystals. [br/][li]	Experimental aspects: Crystallization of proteins. X-ray sources and detectors. X-ray diffraction data collection.[br/][li]	Methods for phase determination in protein crystallography.[br/][b]-	Fibre diffraction[/b][br/][li]	Theory of X-ray diffraction from helical structures (DNA, muscles).[br/][li]	Diffraction from non-helical fibres (amyloid fibres)[br/][b]-	Macromolecules in solution[/b][br/][li]	Wide- and Small-angle X-ray scattering.[br/][b]-	Neutron scattering and diffraction on biological systems[/b][br/][li]	Neutron sources and instrumentation. Interaction of neutrons with biological molecules. Contrast variation methods[br/][li]	Neutron crystallography. Neutron solution scattering[br/][b]-	Electron diffraction and microscopy[/b][br/][li]	Electron diffraction from 2d crystals. Single-particle imaging.[br/][br/][br/][br/][br/]

free_text.Objectifs d'apprentissage: Présentation des principales méthodes physiques propres à l'étude structurale des systèmes macromoléculaires biologiques. Cet enseignement s'adresse tout autant à des étudiants formés aux Sciences Physiques qu'à des étudiants des Sciences de la Vie. A ces derniers, cet enseignement permet d'acquérir une maîtrise conceptuelle des méthodes physiques de la biologie structurale et d'éviter ainsi l'approche largement répandue qui consiste à considérer ces techniques comme des "boîtes noires".
